Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer:
In the evaluation of large language models (LLMs), socially aware bias measurements play a crucial role in assessing the fairness and inclusivity of these models. The presence of biases in LLMs can have significant consequences, as they can perpetuate harmful stereotypes or reinforce existing social inequalities.

Socially aware bias measurements are essential for identifying and addressing these biases, ensuring that LLMs do not inadvertently discriminate against certain groups based on their gender, race, ethnicity, age, or other characteristics. This is particularly important in applications where language models are used to make decisions about individuals, such as hiring, loan approval, or healthcare diagnosis.

Moreover, socially aware bias measurements can help developers and users of LLMs identify and correct biases that may be present in the data used to train these models. By recognizing and addressing these biases, we can create more equitable language models that are better equipped to handle diverse perspectives and promote fair decision-making processes.

Ultimately, socially aware bias measurements are vital for ensuring the responsible development and deployment of LLMs, as they enable developers to build more inclusive and transparent AI systems that do not perpetuate harmful biases.
ground_truth: The significance of socially aware bias measurements for language representations in the field of computational linguistics is that they help identify and quantify biases present in language models and representations. These measurements allow researchers to assess the fairness and inclusivity of these models and address any biases that may exist. By understanding and mitigating biases, computational linguists can develop more equitable and unbiased language technologies that better serve diverse user populations.

ground_truth: The title of the paper mentioned in the context information is "Crows-pairs: A challenge dataset for measuring social biases in masked language models." It was published in the Proceedings of the 2020 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing (EMNLP 2020), edited by Bonnie Webber, Trevor Cohn, Yulan He, and Yang Liu. The publication details include the page range (pp. 1953-1967), the publisher (Association for Computational Linguistics), and the DOI (10.18653/v1/2020.emnlp-main.154).

question: What is the main focus of the paper "CREATOR: disentangling abstract and concrete reasonings of large language models through tool creation" by Cheng Qian, Chi Han, Yi R. Fung, Yujia Qin, Zhiyuan Liu, and Heng Ji?
contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi
Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

ground_truth: The paper "TIMEDIAL: temporal commonsense reasoning in dialog" by Lianhui Qin, Aditya Gupta, Shyam Upadhyay, Luheng He, Yejin Choi, and Manaal Faruqui contributes to the field of natural language processing by exploring temporal commonsense reasoning in dialog. It presents a novel approach to incorporating temporal reasoning into dialog systems, which is an important aspect of natural language understanding. The paper's findings and techniques can potentially improve the performance and capabilities of dialog systems in understanding and generating responses that involve temporal aspects.

answer: The purpose of the Tool Learning tool mentioned in the document is to evaluate the capabilities of large language models (LLMs) in manipulating and creating tools. The functionality of this tool involves assessing an LLM's ability to manipulate existing tools and create new ones, which facilitates its development and application in various domains.
ground_truth: The purpose of the Toolllm tool mentioned in the document is to facilitate large language models in mastering over 16,000 real-world APIs. It provides functionality that helps these models become proficient in utilizing a wide range of application programming interfaces (APIs) commonly used in real-world scenarios. By mastering these APIs, the Toolllm tool enables large language models to better understand and generate code, perform tasks, and interact with various software systems. This tool plays a crucial role in enhancing the capabilities of language models by enabling them to effectively leverage real-world APIs.

answer:
The Tool Learning with Foundation Models approach contributes to the advancement of language models by enabling them to learn and utilize tools, such as mathematical equations or programming languages. This capability allows large language models (LLMs) to manipulate and create new tools, ultimately expanding their capabilities and potential applications.

In the context of the document, this approach is significant because it enables LLMs to demonstrate more sophisticated abilities, such as tool manipulation and creation. This not only showcases the impressive capabilities of LLMs but also highlights the potential risks associated with these advanced AI models, including the possibility of them creating harmful or misleading content.

The significance of Tool Learning with Foundation Models in this document lies in its ability to illustrate the rapid progress being made in the development of LLMs. This advancement has raised concerns about the potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards, making it crucial to conduct rigorous and comprehensive evaluations of LLMs to ensure their safe and beneficial development.

Ultimately, the significance of Tool Learning with Foundation Models in this document is that it underscores the need for a deeper understanding of the capabilities and limitations of LLMs. By exploring the potential applications and risks associated with these AI models, researchers can better guide their evolution into directions that maximize societal benefit while minimizing potential risks.
ground_truth: The Tool learning with foundation models approach contributes to the advancement of language models by facilitating their ability to master over 16,000 real-world APIs. This approach, described in the document, enables large language models to effectively utilize and understand the functionalities of these APIs. By doing so, language models can better interact with and manipulate real-world data and systems, leading to improved performance and applicability in various domains. This significance lies in the fact that language models with enhanced API mastery can be leveraged for a wide range of tasks, such as natural language understanding, information retrieval, and automated programming. Overall, the Tool learning approach expands the capabilities of language models and enhances their practical utility in real-world applications.

Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

answer: The query does not mention the specific paper "Gender bias in coreference resolution" by Rachel Rudinger, Jason Naradowsky, Brian Leonard, and Benjamin Van Durme. The provided context information only contains details about a survey paper titled "Evaluating Large Language Models: A Comprehensive Survey". Therefore, I cannot find an answer to this query based on the given context.
ground_truth: The paper "Gender bias in coreference resolution" by Rachel Rudinger, Jason Naradowsky, Brian Leonard, and Benjamin Van Durme appeared in the Proceedings of the 2018 Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies (NAACL-HLT) in New Orleans, Louisiana, USA.

question: What is the main focus of the paper "Performance of chatgpton USMLE: unlocking the potential of large language models for AI-assisted medical education" by Prabin Sharma et al.?

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

It highlights the importance of understanding and mitigating biases in language generation to ensure fairness and inclusivity in natural language processing applications.

answer: The provided context is a survey paper on evaluating Large Language Models (LLMs), not a specific paper on medical question answering. Therefore, there is no discussion or mention of how LLMs contribute to expert-level medical question answering in the given context.
ground_truth: Language models contribute to expert-level medical question answering by leveraging their large-scale pre-training on diverse medical text data. They can understand and generate human-like responses to medical questions by capturing the complex relationships and patterns in medical knowledge. In the paper "Towards expert-level medical question answering with large language models" by Karan Singhal et al., the authors explore the use of large language models for medical question answering and demonstrate their potential to achieve expert-level performance in this domain.

contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi

{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1
∗Equal contribution
†Corresponding author.

ground_truth: The title of the paper mentioned in the context information is "Findings of the WMT 2020 shared task on machine translation robustness" and it was published in the Proceedings of the Fifth Conference on Machine Translation, WMT@EMNLP 2020. The publication details include the editors (Loïc Barrault, Ondrej Bojar, Fethi Bougares, Rajen Chatterjee, Marta R. Costa-jussà, Christian Federmann, Mark Fishel, Alexander Fraser, Yvette Graham, Paco Guzman, Barry Haddow, Matthias Huck, Antonio Jimeno-Yepes, Philipp Koehn, André Martins, Makoto Morishita, Christof Monz, Masaaki Nagata, Toshiaki Nakazawa, and Matteo Negri), the conference dates (November 19-20, 2020), and the publisher (Association for Computational Linguistics, 2020).

ground_truth: The title of the paper mentioned in the context information is "BEHAVIOR: benchmark for everyday household activities in virtual, interactive, and ecological environments." The publication information includes the editors Aleksandra Faust, David Hsu, and Gerhard Neumann, the conference name "Conference on Robot Learning," the date of the conference (8-11 November 2021), the location (London, UK), the volume number (164) of the Proceedings of Machine Learning Research, and the page range (477-490). The paper can be accessed at the URL https://proceedings.mlr.press/v164/srivastava22a.html.

ground_truth: The main focus of the paper "Robustification of multilingual language models to real-world noise in crosslingual zero-shot settings with robust contrastive pretraining" by Asa Cooper Stickland et al. is to address the challenge of real-world noise in crosslingual zero-shot settings by proposing a robust contrastive pretraining method for multilingual language models.

Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities

beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:

We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation

question: What is the purpose of the Gendered Ambiguous Pronoun (GAP) shared task mentioned in the context information?
contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer:
The Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting technique is a method used to elicit reasoning in large language models. It involves providing the model with a series of intermediate steps or "thoughts" that it can use to arrive at a solution. This approach encourages the model to reason and think critically, rather than simply recalling memorized answers.

The CoT technique works by presenting the model with a problem or question, followed by a sequence of prompts that guide the model's thinking. Each prompt provides additional context or information that helps the model refine its understanding of the problem and develop a solution.

For example, if we want to test a language model's ability to reason about a simple math problem, we might use the following CoT prompts:

* "What is 2 + 2?"
* "Think about what you know about basic arithmetic operations."
* "Consider how you would solve this problem step-by-step."
* "What is your answer?"

By providing these intermediate steps, we encourage the model to reason and think critically about the problem, rather than simply recalling a memorized answer. This approach can help us evaluate a language model's ability to reason and think abstractly, which is an important aspect of human intelligence.

Overall, the Chain-of-Thought prompting technique provides a way to elicit reasoning in large language models by guiding their thinking and encouraging them to develop solutions step-by-step.
ground_truth: The Chain-of-Thought prompting technique elicits reasoning in large language models by providing a series of prompts or questions that guide the model's thinking process. This technique prompts the model to generate coherent and logical responses by encouraging it to consider multiple perspectives and build a chain of reasoning.

ground_truth: The paper "CLUE: A Chinese language understanding evaluation benchmark" by Liang Xu et al. contributes to the field of computational linguistics by introducing a benchmark for evaluating Chinese language understanding systems. This benchmark provides a standardized and comprehensive evaluation framework for assessing the performance of various natural language processing models on Chinese language tasks. It helps researchers and practitioners in the field to compare and analyze different models, identify areas for improvement, and advance the development of Chinese language understanding technologies.

and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer: The provided context does not mention the "React" model or any discussion about it synergizing with reasoning and acting in language models. The context appears to be a survey on evaluating large language models, discussing various aspects of their evaluation, such as knowledge and capability, alignment, and safety. Therefore, I cannot provide an answer based on the given query as there is no relevant information provided.
ground_truth: The React model synergizes reasoning and acting in language models by combining both capabilities. It integrates reasoning, which involves logical thinking and problem-solving, with acting, which involves taking actions based on the reasoning process. This integration allows the language model to not only understand and reason about language but also generate appropriate responses or take actions based on the reasoning.

Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi
Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1
∗Equal contribution
†Corresponding author.

answer: The comprehensive survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation of Large Language Models (LLMs). The significance of the findings lies in providing a thorough understanding of LLMs' capabilities, alignment with societal values and moral principles, and potential risks. This knowledge is crucial for ensuring the safe and beneficial development of LLMs, which can have far-reaching implications for their applications in various domains.

answer: The paper "CORGI-PM: A Chinese corpus for gender bias probing and mitigation" by Ge Zhang, Yizhi Li, Yaoyao Wu, Linyuan Zhang, Chenghua Lin, Jiayi Geng, Shi Wang, and Jie Fu contributes to the field of computational linguistics by providing a new Chinese corpus for probing and mitigating gender bias in language models. This research has implications for the development of more inclusive and unbiased AI systems that can accurately understand and generate text while minimizing harmful biases.
ground_truth: The paper "CORGI-PM: A Chinese corpus for gender bias probing and mitigation" by Ge Zhang, Yizhi Li, Yaoyao Wu, Linyuan Zhang, Chenghua Lin, Jiayi Geng, Shi Wang, and Jie Fu contributes to the field of computational linguistics by introducing a Chinese corpus specifically designed for gender bias probing and mitigation. This corpus can be used to study and address gender bias in natural language processing (NLP) models and systems. It provides researchers with a valuable resource for analyzing and mitigating gender bias in Chinese language applications, advancing the understanding and development of fair and unbiased NLP technologies.

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

ground_truth: The title of the paper authored by Yilun Zhao, Chen Zhao, Linyong Nan, Zhenting Qi, Wenlin Zhang, Xiangru Tang, Boyu Mi, and Dragomir Radev is "Robut: A systematic study of table QA robustness against human-annotated adversarial perturbations." The topic of their research is the robustness of table question answering systems against adversarial perturbations.

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1
